Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I gained a more in depth understanding of Spanish grammar and culture.
A far greater understanding of Spanish grammar and an improved ability to communicate complex ideas using muy existing Spanish vocabulary.
The course improved my ability to use and speak the Spanish language.
My Spanish reading, writing, and speaking skills all improved throughout the semester.
I learned the names of a bunch of tenses
My Spanish skills improved a lot.

The course's readings and movies were interesting and gave insight into the different latinx cultures.

However, the workload was insane, even for a 1.5 credit course. The homework on top of studying for the tests and quizzes and preparing presentations made doing quality work impossible.

I wish the class was less focused on extremely specific, seemingly random, probably unimportant grammatical rules. Unfortunately, I yet again come away from a Yale Spanish class feeling like my speaking hasn't improved that much. But, I've got all 5 types of "clusulas con si" DOWN so I guess that counts for something.
This course is definitely a lot of work but I learned a lot. However, the work load is very heavy during the second half of the semester.

Strengths: Grammar is reinforced throughout the course, making one more cognisant of errors they have been making during lower level courses. The new gramatical structures also helped us include more diversity in our writing and speaking.

Weakness: Took a lot of time and encouraged memorization

The course's presentations and projects require a significant amount of work for the amount of credit attributed to each, and they don't have significant benefit. The online homework system is very finicky, and the online textbook appears to be disabled. Grading is unnecessarily rough. That said, the need to speak exclusively in Spanish did improve my speaking abilities considerably.
There was a ton of work for the course, and it was not always enjoyable. I did not like Las Batallas en el Desierto very much.

Strengths: practice Spanish
Weaknesses: no standardization of grading between sections, books and stories had vocab that was beyond comprehension level

Strengths: learn a lot of Spanish 
Weakness: Grading is hard, and theres no curve.
No, since the workload forces you to choose whether to sacrifice your grade in Spanish or in your other classes.
Yes, but be prepared for the workload, especially during the second half of the semester.
I would not recommend this course, but given that you probably don't have much choice but to take it, it's not going to kill you.
Only if it is the level of Spanish that they are in and they wish to take a Spanish language course
If you gotta take youll get through it.
Yes, if you want to learn Spanish and you dont mind doing a lot of work.
